slide.title: Disclosure
slide.text: Disclosure I have no actual or potential conflict of interest in relation to this program/presentation.

slide.title: What do we worry about in SET?
slide.titleNormalized: what do we worry about in set?
slide.text: What do we worry about in SET? Benign (>85%) Malignant (<15%)

slide.title: EUS (Endoscopic ultrasonography)
slide.notes: As you know, EUS has the merits of endoscopy and ultrasonography. During EUS, we can get some information from the endoscopic findings of subepithelial lesions.
slide.notesNormalized: as you know, eus has the merits of endoscopy and ultrasonography. during eus, we can get some information from the endoscopic findings of subepithelial lesions.
slide.notesHtml:
As you know, EUS has the merits of endoscopy and ultrasonography.

During EUS, we can get some information from the endoscopic findings of subepithelial lesions.
slide.text: EUS (Endoscopic ultrasonography) Endoscopy GI tract surface image Ultrasonography Image of GI wall & adjacent extramural structures High resolution image in near field with limited penetration depth (1-2 cm to 5-6 cm) The most useful diagnostic modality for evaluating GI SETs !

slide.title: Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS)
slide.text: Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) Limitation of EUS Operator-dependent Only 50-60% accuracy for hypoechoic lesions in 3rd/4th layer J Gastroenterol Hepatol 2008;23:556-566

slide.title: Then, is it impossible to differentiate GISTs from leiomyomas on EUS?
slide.titleNormalized: then, is it impossible to differentiate gists from leiomyomas on eus?
slide.text: Then, is it impossible to differentiate GISTs from leiomyomas on EUS? IMPOSSIBLE ? Leiomyoma GIST

slide.title: Differentiate GISTs from leiomyoma by EUS? (n=53)
slide.titleNormalized: differentiate gists from leiomyoma by eus? (n=53)
slide.notes: First, I retrospectively analyzed the EUS features of gastric GISTs and leiomyomas. As a result, the EUS features such as inhomogeneity, hyperechogenic spots, a marginal halo and higher echogenicity as compared with the surrounding muscle layer may help to differentiate GISTs from leiomyomas.
slide.notesNormalized: first, i retrospectively analyzed the eus features of gastric gists and leiomyomas. as a result, the eus features such as inhomogeneity, hyperechogenic spots, a marginal halo and higher echogenicity as compared with the surrounding muscle layer may help to differentiate gists from leiomyomas.
slide.notesHtml:
First, I retrospectively analyzed the EUS features of gastric GISTs and leiomyomas.

As a result, the EUS features such as inhomogeneity, hyperechogenic spots, a marginal halo and higher echogenicity as compared

with the surrounding muscle layer may help to differentiate GISTs from leiomyomas.
slide.text: Differentiate GISTs from leiomyoma by EUS? (n=53) Kim GH et al. World J Gastroenterol 2009;15:3376

slide.title: Interpretation of EUS
slide.text: Interpretation of EUS Subjective & endoscopist-dependent → poor inter-/intra-observer agreement GIST Leiomyoma Schwannoma

slide.notes: Therefore, I tried to transform the subjective information of EUS findings to objective data. There are three main subjective issues in EUS images. To minimize these differences, a standardization process is considered. I will show you later. Heterogeneity can be expressed by dispersion parameters such as SD.
slide.notesNormalized: therefore, i tried to transform the subjective information of eus findings to objective data. there are three main subjective issues in eus images. to minimize these differences, a standardization process is considered. i will show you later. heterogeneity can be expressed by dispersion parameters such as sd.
slide.notesHtml:
Therefore, I tried to transform the subjective information of EUS findings to objective data.

There are three main subjective issues in EUS images.

To minimize these differences, a standardization process is considered. I will show you later.

Heterogeneity can be expressed by dispersion parameters such as SD.
slide.text: EUS images are composed of pixels Echo density is expressed in bright values (0-255) Subjective Objective Echogenicity Mean of brightness Heterogeneity Standard deviation Contrast Standardization

slide.title: Standardization process of EUS image
slide.notes: A standardization process was performed using the brightness values of the anechoic center and outer hyperechoic rim of the EUS scope, which have the least variability.
slide.notesNormalized: a standardization process was performed using the brightness values of the anechoic center and outer hyperechoic rim of the eus scope, which have the least variability.
slide.notesHtml: A standardization process was performed using the brightness values of the anechoic center and outer hyperechoic rim of the EUS scope, which have the least variability.
slide.text: Standardization process of EUS image Kim GH et al. BMC Gastroenterol 2014;14:7

slide.title: Example
slide.text: Example Kim GH et al. BMC Gastroenterol 2014;14:7

slide.title: Tmean/TSD of brightness values after digital image analysis of gastric mesenchymal tumors (n=65)
slide.titleNormalized: tmean/tsd of brightness values after digital image analysis of gastric mesenchymal tumors (n=65)
slide.notes: When an ROC curve was created for differentiating GIST from leiomyoma or schwannoma, the sensitivity and specificity were almost optimized when the critical values of Tmean and TSD were 65 and 75, respectively. The presence of at least 1 of these 2 findings in a given tumor resulted in a sensitivity of 94%, specificity of 80%, positive predictive value of 94%, negative predictive value of 80%, and accuracy of 90.8% for predicting GIST.
slide.notesNormalized: when an roc curve was created for differentiating gist from leiomyoma or schwannoma, the sensitivity and specificity were almost optimized when the critical values of tmean and tsd were 65 and 75, respectively. the presence of at least 1 of these 2 findings in a given tumor resulted in a sensitivity of 94%, specificity of 80%, positive predictive value of 94%, negative predictive value of 80%, and accuracy of 90.8% for predicting gist.
slide.notesHtml:
When an ROC curve was created for differentiating GIST from leiomyoma or schwannoma, the sensitivity and specificity were almost optimized when the critical values of Tmean and TSD were 65 and 75, respectively.

The presence of at least 1 of these 2 findings in a given tumor resulted in a sensitivity of 94%, specificity of 80%, positive predictive value of 94%, negative predictive value of 80%, and accuracy of 90.8% for predicting GIST.
slide.text: Tmean/TSD of brightness values after digital image analysis of gastric mesenchymal tumors (n=65) Kim GH et al. BMC Gastroenterol 2014;14:7 65 75

Subepithelial tumor Color Cyst, Lipoma Vascular lesion Cushion sign Observation (6-12 mo) Surface erosion/ulceration Size ≥ 1 cm EUS Hypoechoic mass in 4th layer < 2 cm 2-5 cm > 5 cm translucent/yellow/bluish Rolling/Tenting sign Biopsy Observation (6 mo) Bite-on-bite biopsy EUS-FNA/FNB Endoscopic resection Operation (+) (+) (-) (-) (+) irregular margin cystic change (-) (-) Approach to SET : PNUH algorithm

slide.title: Tmean/TSD of brightness values after digital image analysis of gastric mesenchymal tumors measuring 2‒5 cm (n=103)
slide.titleNormalized: tmean/tsd of brightness values after digital image analysis of gastric mesenchymal tumors measuring 2‒5 cm (n=103)
slide.notes: Therefore, at this time, I tried to develop a scoring system based on the digital image analysis of EUS images to predict gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs). In univariate analysis, Age, Tmean, and TSD were significantly higher in GISTs than in non-GISTs. The sensitivity and specificity were almost optimized for differentiating GISTs from non-GISTs when the critical values of age, Tmean, and TSD were 57.5 years, 67.0, and 25.6, respectively.
slide.notesNormalized: therefore, at this time, i tried to develop a scoring system based on the digital image analysis of eus images to predict gastrointestinal stromal tumors (gists). in univariate analysis, age, tmean, and tsd were significantly higher in gists than in non-gists. the sensitivity and specificity were almost optimized for differentiating gists from non-gists when the critical values of age, tmean, and tsd were 57.5 years, 67.0, and 25.6, respectively.
slide.notesHtml:
Therefore, at this time, I tried to develop a scoring system based on the digital image analysis of EUS images to predict gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs).

In univariate analysis, Age, Tmean, and TSD were significantly higher in GISTs than in non-GISTs.

The sensitivity and specificity were almost optimized for differentiating GISTs from non-GISTs when the critical values of age, Tmean, and TSD were 57.5 years, 67.0, and 25.6, respectively.
slide.text: Tmean/TSD of brightness values after digital image analysis of gastric mesenchymal tumors measuring 2‒5 cm (n=103) Kim GH et al. Gastric Cancer 2019 Epub 58 67 26

slide.title: Proposed GIST-predicting scoring system
slide.notes: Multivariate logistic regression analysis revealed age ≥ 58 years and Tmean ≥ 67 were relevant independent factors predicting GIST. TSD ≥ 26 was associated with a possibility of GIST, but did not reach statistical significance One point was given for TSD ≥ 26, 2 for age ≥ 58 years, and 3 for Tmean ≥ 67 based on the β-coefficient. When an ROC curve was created to identify the best sensitivity and specificity cut-off values of GIST-PSS for differentiating GISTs from non-GISTs, the sensitivity and specificity were almost optimized when the critical values of GIST-PSS were 2.5. Therefore, a total of three points was defined as the cutoff value between GISTs and non-GISTs. The sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy of the GIST-PSS were 86.5%, 75.9%, and 83.5%, respectively
slide.notesNormalized: multivariate logistic regression analysis revealed age ≥ 58 years and tmean ≥ 67 were relevant independent factors predicting gist. tsd ≥ 26 was associated with a possibility of gist, but did not reach statistical significance one point was given for tsd ≥ 26, 2 for age ≥ 58 years, and 3 for tmean ≥ 67 based on the β-coefficient. when an roc curve was created to identify the best sensitivity and specificity cut-off values of gist-pss for differentiating gists from non-gists, the sensitivity and specificity were almost optimized when the critical values of gist-pss were 2.5. therefore, a total of three points was defined as the cutoff value between gists and non-gists. the sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy of the gist-pss were 86.5%, 75.9%, and 83.5%, respectively
slide.notesHtml:
Multivariate logistic regression analysis revealed age ≥ 58 years and Tmean ≥ 67 were relevant independent

factors predicting GIST. TSD ≥ 26 was associated with a possibility of GIST, but did not reach statistical significance

One point was given for TSD ≥ 26, 2 for age ≥ 58 years, and 3 for Tmean ≥ 67 based on the β-coefficient.

When an ROC curve was created to identify the best sensitivity and specificity cut-off values of GIST-PSS for differentiating GISTs

from non-GISTs, the sensitivity and specificity were almost optimized when the critical values of GIST-PSS were 2.5.

Therefore, a total of three points was defined as the cutoff value between GISTs and non-GISTs.

The sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy of the GIST-PSS were 86.5%, 75.9%, and 83.5%, respectively
slide.text: Proposed GIST-predicting scoring system Kim GH et al. Gastric Cancer 2019 Epub Score 2.5 ROC area = 0.861

slide.title: Future GIST-predicting scoring system → Computer-aided diagnosis system
slide.titleNormalized: future gist-predicting scoring system → computer-aided diagnosis system
slide.notes: For future GIST-predicting scoring system, more information such as size, ratio of width and height, and location of tumor should be included. In addition, a system with a higher accuracy and clinical validation and real time performance is needed.
slide.notesNormalized: for future gist-predicting scoring system, more information such as size, ratio of width and height, and location of tumor should be included. in addition, a system with a higher accuracy and clinical validation and real time performance is needed.
slide.notesHtml:
For future GIST-predicting scoring system, more information such as size, ratio of width and height, and location of tumor should be included.

In addition, a system with a higher accuracy and clinical validation and real time performance is needed.
slide.text: Future GIST-predicting scoring system → Computer-aided diagnosis system Higher accuracy Clinical validation Real-time

slide.title: Computer-aided diagnosis system
slide.notes: These two algorithms have the pros and cons. Therefore, in the future, CAD based on the combination of these two algorithms would be ideal.
